messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Japanese Terms
messages.msgSnippet: David et all- ŠÓÜ Kansho - Appreciation - does not necessarily imply all the ceremony. Some blades are laid out for kantei and others just for
messages.messageBody:
David et all-

ÓÜ
Kansho - Appreciation - does not necessarily imply all the ceremony. Some
blades are laid out for kantei and others just for appreciation
(kansho-to). The etiquette for taking out and examining a sword is called
Kansho Saho (ÓÜì@)
èüÆÛ¶
Teire -Care - and conservation (or preservation)
Û¶@
Hozon-ho - Rules for conservation

Is there a Kansho-shiki (ceremony)? I think Kansho-saho is what you are
looking for...
-t


Original Message:
-----------------
From: David McDonald jswords@...
Date: Mon, 02 Feb 2009 12:08:17 -0700
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Japanese Terms


Dear All

I had an email that I could not answer. Maybe some out there knows.

1.WHAT IS THE JAPANESE TERM FOR "FORMALY EXAMINING THE BLADE". (KNEELING
IN SEIZA, REMOVING THE SWORD FROM BAG, LAYING IT IN-FRONT OF ONES SELF,
BOWING TO THE SWORD, PICKING UP THE SWORD, INSPECTING KODOGU, REMOVING
SAYA, EXAMINING THE BLADE, ECT.)

2.SECOND QUESTION IS WHAT IS THE JAPANESE TERM FOR "CLEANING THE BLADE".

Thanks
david

--
David McDonald Collector of Japanese Swords and Old Iron
PO Box 265 WEB page - http://www.montanairon.com

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Japanese Terms
messages.msgSnippet: Hi David, I am not sure there are terms for these, but the best source to find out is the Nihonto Yogo Jiten or Dictionary of Japanese Sword Terms, which is at
messages.messageBody:
Hi David,



I am not sure there are terms for these, but the best source to find out is
the Nihonto Yogo Jiten or Dictionary of Japanese Sword Terms, which is at
home, and I am at school. If someone has this book, there is a section in
the back on cleaning and proper handling and if there are associated terms,
there will be there.



Gordon



_____
